definition: Zhong Kui (mythological figure, supposed to drive away evil spirits)/(fig.) a person with the courage to fight against evil
clock/o'clock/time as measured in hours and minutes/bell/CL:架[jia4],座[zuo4]
handleless cup/goblet/to concentrate/variant of 鐘|钟[zhong1]
surname Zhong
cheekbone/crossroads/high

sentences.english: Zhong Kui married off his little sister to Du Ping in return.
sentences.chinese: 钟馗为了感恩，把妹妹嫁给了杜平。

sentences.english: Another saying is that his town fellow, Du Ping buried him after his death.
sentences.chinese: 又说，钟馗死后，他的同乡好友杜平为他安葬。

sentences.english: Acting as both the judge and the executor, Zhong Kui punishes vice and rewards virtue.
sentences.chinese: 钟馗既是法官又是执行者，他惩恶扬善。

sentences.english: The Picture of Zhong Kui Marrying off his Sister was very popular at that time.
sentences.chinese: 当年有一幅《钟馗嫁妹》图，在民间是十分流行的。

sentences.english: Furious, Zhong Kui killed himself and became the spirit of catching ghosts.
sentences.chinese: 钟馗暴跳如雷，当场自杀，死后就成了捉鬼的神灵。

definition: Di Renjie (607-700), Tang dynasty politician, prime minister under Wu Zetian, subsequently hero of legends/master sleuth Judge Dee, aka Chinese Sherlock Holmes, in novel Three murder cases solved by Judge Dee 狄公案[Di2 gong1 an4] translated by Dutch sinologist R.H. van Gulik 高羅珮|高罗佩[Gao1 Luo2 pei4]

Diaochan (-192), one of the four legendary beauties 四大美女[si4 da4 mei3 nu:3], in fiction a famous beauty at the break-up of Han dynasty, given as concubine to usurping warlord Dong Zhuo 董卓[Dong3 Zhuo2] to ensure his overthrow by fighting hero Lü Bu 呂布|吕布[Lu:3 Bu4]
cheekbone/crossroads/high
Cheng Yaojin (589-665), aka 程知節|程知节[Cheng2 Zhi1 jie2], Chinese general of the Tang dynasty
Dharma, the teaching of Buddha/Bodhidharma
Houyi, mythological Chinese archer whose wife was Chang'e
秦越人[Qin2 Yue4 ren2] (407-310 BC), Warring States physician known for his medical skills, nicknamed Bian Que after the earliest known Chinese physician allegedly from the 黃帝|黄帝[Huang2 di4] era
Nezha, protection deity
same as Zhuangzi 莊子|庄子 (369-286 BC), Daoist author
Lu Ban, legendary master craftsman, called the father of Chinese carpentry

Jiang Ziya (c. 1100 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), partly mythical sage advisor to King Wen of Zhou 周文王[Zhou1 Wen2 wang2] and purported author of “Six Secret Strategic Teachings” 六韜|六韬[Liu4 tao1], one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1]
Daji (c. 11th century BC), concubine of the last Shang dynasty king Zhou Xin 紂辛|纣辛[Zhou4 Xin1]
Ying Zheng (260-210 BC), personal name of the first emperor 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2]
Wang Zhaojun (52-19 BC), famous beauty at the court of Han emperor Yuan 漢元帝|汉元帝[Han4 Yuan2 di4], one of the four legendary beauties 四大美女[si4 da4 mei3 nu:3]
Sun Bin (-316 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (425-221 BC)

Guan Yu (-219), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, fearsome fighter famous for virtue and loyalty/posthumously worshipped and identified with the guardian Bodhisattva Sangharama
